ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about the intersection between Jewish Mysticism and Christianity in out evolved throughout western philosophy and theology in post reformation era.

We read numerous obscure and niche authors and had insight to their influence on both the theological and philosophical aspects, which is something very difficult to curate and well done in this course to open up avenues of thought that expand in myriad directions, allowing for independent thinking and unusual and exciting conclusions. I learned a lot from reading the comprehensive Canvas posts from the other students.
I learned a lot about Kabbalah, Lutherism, and the way that these two religious traditions have been taken up by, and influenced, German Idealist philosophers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Prof Franks and Prof Stern are a dynamic duo and complement each other so well with their specialty areas. Everyone I know in the course learned so much and was able to explore their personal interests as they relate to broader Idealism. I could not imagine a better curated or more holistic course, as we examined both the thematic, historical, theological, and rhetorical aspects of thinkers.

The syllabus for this course was really great, and I loved how the professors engaged with students during the class (ie answering questions). I also liked how paper topics were centered around specific quotes from the readings, which made us really dig into the text while writing.

However, the course's lecture format was disappointing. The class was originally listed as a seminar, and I wish that the professors had limited enrollment so that there could be more discussion and close-reading around a seminar table. As taught, the lectures often felt dry (or just long), and mostly recapped the readings themselves rather than broadening into a more synthetic group discussion. Doing the course as a lecture made it hard to really feel engaged in the course.

Furthermore, I feel that the course's emphasis on Luther and Kabbalah could have been more clear from the get-go. I was under the impression that the course would be more of a "survey" of the religious underpinnings of German Idealism, and instead it taught a more specific set of connections. These connections were, however, fascinating, and certainly worth studying.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Interest in German Idealism is definitely needed to put in the thought to tie the readings together and approach conclusions independently, but this is the type of course that consumes one's excess intellectual energy to the point of seeing the whole world in terms of Idealism, and its very exciting.
As currently taught, I would only recommend this course to another student who had a very strong, internally motivated interest in the topics at hand.
